title: Viva Max!
descriptions:
Viva Max! is a 1969 American comedy film directed by Jerry Paris and starring Peter Ustinov, John Amos, and Jonathan Winters. The movie is set during the Vietnam War and revolves around a satirical take on the anti-war movement.

The film tells the story of Max Slaten (played by Peter Ustinov), a charming but dim-witted World War I veteran who is convinced that he is still a hero. Max is tired of living in a world where he feels he doesn't belong and decides to join the anti-war movement by claiming that he has a plan to tunnel under the Hudson River and smuggle anti-war protesters from Canada into New York City.

However, Max's plan is not as clever as he thinks it is, and it quickly falls apart. He enlists the help of a group of bumbling protesters, including a young woman named Maxine (played by Pamela Smith), and a black activist named Billy (played by Jonathan Winters). Together, they embark on a series of misadventures as they try to execute Max's plan.

As the story unfolds, Max's antics become more and more absurd, and the film becomes a commentary on the excesses and hypocrisy of the anti-war movement. Despite its satirical tone, the movie also has a lighthearted and comedic feel to it, with plenty of physical humor and witty one-liners.

Throughout the film, Peter Ustinov shines as the lovable but buffoonish Max Slaten, bringing a sense of energy and enthusiasm to the role. The supporting cast, including John Amos and Jonathan Winters, also deliver strong performances, adding to the film's comedic charm.

Overall, Viva Max! is a clever and entertaining comedy that uses satire to poke fun at the anti-war movement of the 1960s. With its lighthearted tone and absurd humor, the film is a fun and nostalgic look back at a pivotal moment in American history.
